awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Electrically charged polymers, called polyelectrolytes, are common in biology and include DNA, RNA, proteins, and mucous layers.  They are increasingly used for applications ranging from drug delivery to membranes for sensing or batteries.  Membranes of polyelectrolytes for these applications can be built up, layer by layer, by sequentially dipping a surface into a negatively charged polyelectrolyte followed by dipping into a positively charged one.  Additionally, gels swollen with water, known as "coacervates", can be made by mixing two oppositely charged polyelectrolytes.  Despite the importance of these materials in biology and advanced applications, their behavior is poorly known, and neither the properties of coacervates nor the rate of growth of layer-by-layer membranes is understood at present. While promising theories for such polyelectrolyte materials have recently been developed, there is little systematic experimental data to test and confirm these theories so as to help design advanced materials.  To provide such tests, this project will use both simple and advanced experimental methods to measure the composition of coacervates, and the growth rate and thickness of layer-by-layer films.  These measurements will be carried out systematically with varying salt concentration and pH to establish quantitative trends needed to test and confirm newly developed theory and provide a firm base for design of advanced materials made from polyelectrolytes.  Such knowledge is also relevant in biological systems, including the interactions of positively charged proteins with negatively charged DNA, which controls the structure and function of chromosomes.  Beyond the research, broader impacts of this project will include the education of graduate and undergraduate students, outreach, and development of specialized computational codes relevant to this topic.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

To understand and test theories for the equilibrium and dynamics of assemblies of oppositely charged polyelectrolytes, several phases of study will be performed. First, the phase behavior including compositions of individual polyions in both coacervate and supernatant phases for four common polyelectrolyte mixtures will be measured by high pressure liquid chromatography, proton NMR, and other methods. The results will be compared to the predictions of new theories, and used to test and improve these theories. Titrations with acid and base will be used to determine ion pairing equilibrium constants, ionization equilibrium, and thermodynamic "chi" parameters. In addition, Layer-by-Layer (LbL) growth rates for these polyelectrolytes will be measured and the thermodynamic information determined by theory and phase behavior will be used to predict these growth rates.  The diffusivities of polyions through the polyelectrolyte multilayer needed for predictions of LbL growth will be inferred from strengths of ion pairing obtained from atomistic molecular dynamics (MD) simulations of a polyanion and polycation in water and salt.

por.por_cntn:
A remaining classical field of polymer science for which understanding remains poor is that of so-called “coacervates.” These are gel-like or viscous complexes formed by mixing water-soluble oppositely charged polymers, or “polyelectrolytes” in salts and water. Recognition of the importance of these materials dates back 100 years to Oparin, who speculated that coacervate droplets might be “proto-cells,” or precursors of life.  Oparin’s hypothesis has proved to be too simple, since nucleic-acid polymers, specifically DNA and RNA, are now known to be the carriers of genetic information essential to life.  Nevertheless, DNA and RNA, are, like proteins, are charged polymers that form complexes with oppositely charged proteins, the most well-known of which are chromosomes, which are exquisitely structured complexes of DNA and proteins held together by charge interactions. 

 

Complexes formed by synthetic polyelectrolytes are vastly cruder than DNA and proteins, and yet carry the possibility of refinement, and an ever-expanding wealth of possible applications.  Polyelectrolytes are already used or explored for application in drug release compounds, vaccines, underwater adhesives, and others, as reviewed recently by Liu et al. (Adv. Coll. Interf. Sci. Matter 239, 46-60 (2017)).  Even these simpler polyelectrolyte complexes remain poorly understood, although rapid progress is currently being made. The key to gaining the understanding needed to design coacervates and their properties is a combination of advanced polymer theory and well-designed experiments that can test theoretical ideas and refine them.

 

The work performed under NSF DMR 1707640, “Polyelectrolyte Phase Behavior and Transport,” provided significant new insight into the forces driving formation of polyelectrolyte complexes. In simpler cases, often involving elevated salt concentrations or weaker charge levels, the coacervates reach a unique equilibrium state that is independent of how the polyelectrolytes, salts, and water are mixed. For these cases, our work under the grant developed a novel method of thoroughly characterizing the concentrations of both positively and negatively charged polyelectrolytes in each of the two separate phases formed after mixing the components. Each phase has five components:  two polyelectrolytes (one positive and one negative), two salt ions (one positive and one negative) and water. This complexity makes determination of composition difficult, but we have learned to address it through use of a variety of known methods, plus a new one: the use of carbon-13 based NMR, or nuclear magnetic resonance, a well-known method, but not hitherto used for this purpose. 

 

In addition, we addressed the common situations in which the order of addition of polyelectrolytes controls the material and its properties. The most useful way of exploiting this effect of mixing order is through “layer-by-layer” assembly. In this method the positively and negatively charged polyelectrolytes are alternatively deposited on a surface, building up a stratified or layered structure. Such materials are useful in drug-release applications, and in ultra-tough hard materials, with layering reminiscent of clam or oyster shells. We address this situation by depositing polyelectrolytes sequentially onto a quartz crystal, whose vibrations are sensitive to added mass, allowing the amounts of mass deposited, and the rates of deposition, to be measured precisely.  This work provided the first “inside look” at the actual rates of deposition of such layers and at how their structure responds to changes in salt concentration and pH.  In particular, we found the remarkable result that even a single polyelectrolyte layer is sensitive to the sequence by which pH changes, creating the ability to shrink and swell these layers in a manner controlled by pH sequence, creating pH-responsive gels that are a single molecular layer thick.

 

The work resulted in 15 publications in first-rate journals, and contributed substantially to the training of four Ph.D. students (one of them minority, and two women) and two undergraduate students. One of the Ph.D. students has graduated and is working in industry, at 3M. Broader impacts also included writing a major review article on the mechanical properties of coacervates. Making good use of the temporary lab shutdown necessitated by the Covid 19 pandemic, two of the experimental Ph.D. students participated with the PI in the writing of a review article on the extensive literature regarding the mechanical properties or “rheology” of polyelectrolyte coacervates. This review article will serve this rapidly expanding field, and made the students on the project more productive once labs opened again. Another broader impact was the production of software to predict coacervate phase behavior under a variety of salt and pH conditions, and under an excess of one or the other polyelectrolyte.  An early version of this software was exploited by researchers at Stanford, and is now being used at Procter and Gamble to help predict the behavior of polyelectrolyte solutions used in their hair-care products. The student who developed the software under the NSF grant is now working as a student researcher at Procter and Gamble, using the software to impact commercial products.
